column1: A raven is one of several larger-bodied species of the genus Corvus. These species do not form a single taxonomic group within the genus.
There is no consistent distinction between "crows" and "ravens"
column2: and these appellations have been assigned to different species chiefly on the basis of their size
column3: crows generally being smaller than ravens.

column1: The largest raven species are the common raven and the thick-billed raven.
The term "raven" originally referred to the common raven (Corvus corax)
column2: the type species of the genus Corvus
column3: which has a larger distribution than any other species of Corvus
column4: ranging over much of the Northern Hemisphere.

column1: The modern English word raven has cognates in all other Germanic languages
column2: including Old Norse (and subsequently modern Icelandic) hrafn and Old High German (h)raban
column3: all of which descend from Proto-Germanic *hrabanaz.Collective nouns for a group of ravens (or at least the common raven) include "unkindness"
column6: most people use the more generic "flock".
